key_anomalies.description: Outbreak onset 3-4 weeks earlier than typical seasonality in EU/EEA
Significant antigenic divergence of H3N2 subclade K from vaccine strain
US NCHS mortality surveillance data unavailable weeks 39-47
First US death attributed to H5N5 amid seasonal H3N2 circulation

data_gaps_identified: US national surveillance pause since September 26, 2025
Limited country-level counts across WHO regions
Japan official national surveillance data sparse
Australia official reports exist but counts not extracted

anomaly_flags.description: Only 33.3% of H3N2 viruses well recognized by vaccine
6 of 7 characterized K-clade viruses showed low reactivity
NA K249E and PA I38L mutations detected in small numbers
Official national surveillance data limited, relies on media reports
Early peak reported with 96% subclade K in small sample

JPN.primary_data_source: Japan Institute for Health Security (media cited)

anomaly_flags.description: Adelaide ED at 125%+ capacity with admitted patients exceeding bed spaces
Extended ED stays and admitted patients blocking ED capacity
FluWatch+ portal inaccessible, limited federal data
Northern Ontario experiencing early seasonal surge with COVID-19 co-circulation
Active monitoring for emerging respiratory diseases including hMPV
Limited detailed H3N2 counts publicly available
Detections rising 3-4 weeks earlier than usual
Significant antigenic divergence of subclade K from vaccine strain
Expected seasonal burden: up to 50M symptomatic cases, 15K-70K deaths

pathogen_cross_analysis.findings: RSV activity increasing in children 0-4 years in southeastern, southern, mid-Atlantic regions of US
H3N2 predominance with COVID-19 at very low levels nationally; JN.1 variant of interest
First US H5N5 death amid seasonal H3N2 circulation; no evidence of human-to-human transmission

anomalies_detected.description: SureScreen test shows specificity below WHO recommendations (86.2%)
All lateral flow tests show decreased performance at low viral loads (CT â‰¥30)

mismatch_indicators.evidence_source: ECDC Phylogenetic/Serologic analysis; UKHSA antigenic characterization

key_epidemiological_events.description: National CDC respiratory surveillance pause begins, limiting situational awareness
First US death attributed to influenza A(H5N5) amid seasonal H3N2 circulation
ECDC confirms H3N2 subclade K accounts for ~33% global, ~50% EU/EEA of A(H3N2) sequences
Royal Adelaide Hospital ED at 125%+ capacity with admitted patients exceeding bed spaces
Japan reports early flu peak with 96% subclade K prevalence in small sample

surveillance_gaps.reason: Federal shutdown leaves critical gap in surveillance
NCHS mortality surveillance data not available weeks 39-47
Official national surveillance data limited; relies on media reports

key_findings: Parts of Western/Eastern Africa, Northern Europe >30% positivity

ecdc_reports.subclade_k_assessment: Significant antigenic divergence from vaccine strain; ~50% EU/EEA prevalence

key_signals.description: Multiple reports of hospital overcrowding, especially in Adelaide
Frequent mentions of H3N2 and subclade K in health discussions
Social media discussions about potential vaccine mismatch

key_observations: ED at 125% capacity with admitted patients blocking treatment spaces
All 68 ED treatment spaces occupied by admitted inpatients
Hidden ramping phenomenon affecting patient care
Early seasonal surge in influenza and COVID-19
Staffing challenges due to prolonged patient stays

suspicious_patterns.description: H3N2 detections rising 3-4 weeks earlier than usual seasonal patterns across EU/EEA and Northern Europe
suspicious_patterns.potential_implications: Early season wave may lead to capacity overload and higher cumulative burden
recommended_actions: Prepare surge capacity in healthcare systems
Issue public health advisories for early detection

suspicious_patterns.description: H3N2 subclade K shows significant antigenic divergence from 2025-26 vaccine strain with only 33.3% well recognition
suspicious_patterns.potential_implications: Reduced vaccine effectiveness may lead to higher attack rates and severe outcomes
recommended_actions: Communicate potential reduced protection against infection
Emphasize vaccination benefits against severe disease
Consider booster strategies for high-risk groups

suspicious_patterns.description: US NCHS mortality surveillance unavailable for weeks 39-47, creating critical data blind spot during outbreak acceleration
suspicious_patterns.potential_implications: Unable to assess true mortality burden; complicates risk communication

suspicious_patterns.description: First US death attributed to H5N5 occurs amid seasonal H3N2 circulation, requiring immediate investigation for potential changes
suspicious_patterns.potential_implications: Potential zoonotic transmission event requiring urgent epidemiological investigation
recommended_actions: Sequence case virus to confirm identification
Investigate exposure history and transmission patterns

suspicious_patterns.description: Adelaide ED operating at 125%+ capacity with admitted patients exceeding bed spaces, indicating systemic healthcare failure
suspicious_patterns.potential_implications: Patient safety risks, delayed care, potential mortality increases
recommended_actions: Consider patient transfers to other facilities

potential_misclassification_warnings.description: SureScreen multiplex lateral flow test shows specificity of only 86.2%, below WHO recommendations, creating false positive risk
All lateral flow tests show decreased performance at low viral loads (CT â‰¥30), increasing false negative rates
ILINet captures respiratory illness from multiple pathogens; rising ILI without corresponding influenza positivity may indicate RSV, Mycoplasma, or other pathogens

information_suppression_evidence.description: US CDC respiratory surveillance systems paused since September 26, 2025, creating critical data gap during outbreak period
NCHS mortality surveillance data unavailable for weeks 39-47, preventing assessment of influenza-related mortality

surveillance_gaps.description: Complete federal respiratory surveillance pause in US
surveillance_gaps.potential_impact: Complete loss of national situational awareness during critical outbreak period

surveillance_gaps.description: FluWatch+ portal inaccessible, limiting federal influenza surveillance in Canada
surveillance_gaps.potential_impact: Reduced visibility into Canadian influenza patterns

surveillance_gaps.description: Limited official national surveillance data available for Japan; reliance on media sources
surveillance_gaps.potential_impact: Uncertain assessment of outbreak scale and trajectory

surveillance_gaps.description: US NCHS mortality data unavailable weeks 39-47
surveillance_gaps.potential_impact: Cannot assess true mortality burden during outbreak acceleration
